Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Expanding the Reach of Topological Data Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Data science and analysis have taken a center stage in modern years for a swath of applications<br/>embracing daily life. In general, AI and machine learning have been the backbone of this<br/>development. Recently, a technique based on the classical mathematical area of topology has evolved<br/>that is showing promise to complement and in some cases be an alternative to AI techniques. As this<br/>emergent area, known as topological data analysis (TDA), expands its reach, the task of extracting<br/>intelligent summaries out of diverse, complex data becomes increasingly challenging. To meet this<br/>challenge, TDA also needs to expand its current repertoire of techniques by making further and<br/>deeper connections between mathematical and algorithmic concepts. This project aims to develop<br/>these techniques while training graduate students and other workforce in data science as a<br/>consequence.<br/><br/>The project, in particular, will investigate several novel mathematical concepts in conjunction with<br/>computations to address various challenges appearing in the following topics: (i) augmenting<br/>topological summarization with geometry, (ii) connecting discrete Morse theory to further<br/>applications, (iii) developing persistence theory for combinatorial dynamical systems, and (iv)<br/>developing multi-parameter persistence from a computational view-point. A successful algorithmic<br/>theory supported by sound mathematics for the four aforementioned themes can provide a powerful<br/>tool for data exploration and analysis in a spectrum of engineering and scientific fields. The<br/>proposed outreach activities will also further consolidate the ongoing effort of bringing together<br/>different communities in science and engineering engaged into modern data analysis. The project<br/>will help train graduate students who will develop skills in mathematics and theoretical<br/>computer science, most notably in algorithms and topology, in writing efficient and usable software,<br/>and in its application to analyzing real-world data sets. Efforts will be made to recruit and mentor<br/>students from under-represented groups, as has already been done by the investigator.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
